qas.question: Does the amount of white matter in the brain increase or decrease over the course of adolescence?
Does the amount of grey matter in the brain increase linearly or follow an inverted-U pattern over the course of adolescence?
During which process are unnecessary neuronal connections in the brain eliminated?
Does the brain become more or less efficient as a result of synaptic pruning?

context: Over the course of adolescence, the amount of white matter in the brain <a0_0>increases<a0_0/> linearly, while the amount of grey matter in the brain follows an <a1_0>inverted-U pattern<a1_0/>. Through a process called <a2_0>synaptic pruning<a2_0/>, unnecessary neuronal connections in the brain are eliminated and the amount of grey matter is pared down. However, this does not mean that the brain loses functionality; rather, it becomes <a3_0>more efficient<a3_0/> due to increased myelination (insulation of axons) and the reduction of unused pathways.
